title: The New Paradigm for Financial Markets
author: George Soros
notes: Reflexivity distinguishes only two functions: the cognitive and the manipulative; The uncertainty associated with reflexivity affects not only the participants but also the social scientists who seek to establish universally valid laws governing human behavior

title: Credit Investor’s Handbook (chapter 2-6)
author: Michael Gatto
notes: Credit availability is highly convex to small macro shocks: marginal tightening in economic conditions causes a disproportionate contraction in lending standards, widening credit spreads, falling secondary prices, and rising defaults, which then feeds back into weaker growth. Excess returns in credit are earned by aligning leverage, risk exposure, and liquidity with the cycle—underwriting aggressively only when spreads overcompensate for default and recovery risk, and retrenching when capital is cheap and underwriting standards deteriorate

title: Language AND The Brain
author: Jonathan Brennan
notes: Human language processing is implemented as an online, predictive computation in which left-hemisphere fronto-temporal circuits incrementally map continuous sensory input onto discrete linguistic representations, with distinct neural populations encoding phonological structure, lexical activation, semantic composition, and syntactic dependency formation on separable time courses. The hard problem—and the book’s core claim—is that meaningful progress only comes from committing to explicit linking hypotheses that tie formal linguistic theory to measurable neural dynamics, rather than treating brain activation as an explanation in itself.

title: The Art And Science of Technical Analysis
author: Adam Grimes
status: reading (and don't think will ever finish)

title: The Most Important Thing
author: Howard Marks
notes: superior investing comes not from forecasts but from disciplined second-level thinking—understanding cycles, psychology, and risk better than others when it matters most. The deepest edge is not being right on average, but avoiding being wrong at the extremes by acting countercyclically with humility and patience.

title: The Inner Game of Tennis
author: Timothy Gallwey
notes: peak performance comes from quieting the ego-driven, judgmental mind so the body’s natural intelligence can operate without interference. Mastery is less about trying harder and more about removing internal obstacles—fear, overcontrol, and self-criticism—that prevent what we already know how to do from emerging

title: Adaptive Markets: Financial Evolution at the Speed of Thought
author: Andrew Lo

title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
author: Matthew Walkers
